The woman's husband shot a pig.
I am going to granny's house.
The girl's mother caught a fish.
He/she is afraid of the child's dog.
The man's mother's house is big.
He came from the girl's elder brother's house.
I go to the woman with the baby.
The wild young chap drank alcohol.
I know the man with the spear.
He ran from the place with the ghost.
That Aborigine is deaf.
I have no money.
The trees have no flowers.
The one without a dog found no pigs.
I want meat without bones.
They gave clothes to the girl with no money.
old men
own children
mosquitoes
salt-water crocodiles
trees
The roads are wet and slippery.
The girls dug up a lot of pipis.
He was asking around for food among his friends.

items.transcript: Jana-nda mani-nka manyarr-karra-ngka yalama-ny Dunga-y kuyu
items.phonetic: dʒana-nda mani-nka maɲar-kara-ŋka dʒalama-ɲ dunga-j kuju
items.translation: The wives said to them: "Go to get some fish!"

items.transcript: N gamu-karra nganjan-karra school-mun-bu dunga-y teacher-mun-unji balka-wa-nka
items.phonetic: n gamu-kara ŋandʒan-kara school-mun-bu dunga-j teacher-mun-undʒi balka-wa-nka
items.translation: The mothers and fathers go to the school to talk with the teacher.
The two women burnt the ghost with [burning] grass trees.
The pair of horses is coming.
Two horses are running to the river.
A pair of trees is standing there.
I saw two trees.
He always eats meat. / He is a habitual meat-eater.
The Mossman people went to the Bloomfield people.
The scrub people killed many cassowaries.
I am scared of the wild one.
The womaniser raped a girl.
There is too much drinking going on around here!

gloss.gloss: irritating noise of people shouting and laughing

items.translation: There is too much noise around here!
Charlie is an expert stockman.
The good cook cut up the fish.
Ask the dillybag expert about dillybags!
Her child is rather small.
He sat on a rather ripe mango.
A rather wild dog bit my dog.
Sea-turtle meat is softer than beef.
I am very hungry.
The baby is very cute.
The very strong man lifted the pig up.
I am sorry for the very sick child.
I go for a walk with the childless one.
They came back with the mothers' clothes.
A ghost stole the two women's children.
The Banabila-people's dogs are fierce.
Don't go with that drunkard!
The boss is talking with the young men.
The pregnant woman's husband died.
He ran [off] with the policeman's rifle.
The very big man's spear broke.
He went with a very old car.
[My] child hit the dog.
The wife is cooking food.
I go to [my] younger sister.
She came with [her] mother-in-law.
The husband is looking after the baby.
I asked [my] elder brother.
(my) right side
left foot

items.phonetic: buliman aŋka ŋajku ŋandʒan naka wundiɲ
items.translation: The police took my father "Cairns-way".
Mary is standing close to Queenie.
He came from the other side of the river.
I hear a song from a long way away.
People are singing out from down there.
The old woman followed him. OR '... followed from behind.'
The young man jumped [out] from behind the tree.
He became ill yesterday.
Tomorrow he will go to see the doctor.
I keep some food for later on today.
He has been keeping some old clothes from a long time [ago].
He got a rock and set it up for the next time.
I hit Carol with them.
I saw his elder brother.
My dog bit a child.
My dog bit a child.
I like your mother very much.
Give this money to your [dual] father!
A policeman is coming from their house.
He took your child's food.

items.transcript: N gayku-wun-bul-du babarr-andamun-du kaya-ngka ngayku minya ngaki-ny.
items.phonetic: n gajku-wun-bul-du bababr-andamun-du kaja-ŋka ŋajku minja ŋaki-ɲ
items.translation: My elder sister's dog stole my meat.
Why did you take the dog into the house?

items.transcript: Wanyurringku yundu kaya wundi-ny bayan-ba, ngalkal-ba-ku bawa-nyaku.
items.phonetic: wanjurriŋku jundu kaja wundiɲ bajanba, ŋalkalbaku bawɲaku.
items.translation: What did you take the dog into the house for, you should have left it outside.
What are you ill with?
Where is your mother?
Where are you going?

items.transcript: Yunu scissors wundi! Ngayku scissors wanjabu.
items.phonetic: junu scissors wundi! ŋajku scissors wanjabu.
items.translation: Bring (take) your scissors! My scissors are somewhere (I don't know where I put them).
How did you come back?
How do you cook freshwater eel?
Which one is your house?
What kind of fish did they get?
What kind of people are they?

items.transcript: Yundu wanjanguy-ngku kambi-ka wawu, yinya-ka nganka-nganka-jirr-ka?
items.phonetic: jundu wandʒanguj-ŋku kambi-ka wawu, jinja-ka ŋanka-ŋanka-dʒir-ka?
items.translation: Which kind of dress do you like, the one with the flower pattern?

items.phonetic: jalu-ŋku dʒalbu-ŋku ŋaɲa binal-bungaɲ mara-ka. zamia.nut-DAT
items.translation: This woman taught me about zamia nuts.
They were searching for that child.
Give the letter to that [person].
He is running from here.
I found a lot of scrubhen [eggs] there.
He sat there, on the rock.
decide, be happy
listen
forget
think
jump
long for, crave
say, do
The young man is splitting firewood.
A thunderstorm will come soon.
The man sharpened the knife.
The Aborigine turned back and came back to his camp.
The child fell ill.
Don't chase the horse!
Put your pants on!
Go back!
Don't shout!
Put the baby on the blanket!
Wash your hands!
Learn language!
Heat [it] up!
Don't drop [it]!
I would go/would have gone fishing [but I cannot for some reason].

items.transcript: N gayu nuka-nyaku minya, kari yinya minya kabu.
items.phonetic: n gayu nuka-ɲaku minja, kari jiɲa minja kabu.
items.translation: I would have eaten that meat, but it was rotten.
I want to cook some food.
He knows how to spear.

items.transcript: Jana makarr wundi-ny kuyu wubul bangka-nka.
items.phonetic: dʒana makar wundi-ɲ kuju wubul baŋka-nka.
items.translation: They took a net to catch a lot of fish.
I go with a friend lest I get lonely.
Burn some ironwood to prevent the thunderstorm from coming!
They had finished the food before their father woke up.
He cried out before he died.

items.transcript: N gayu bambay-ma-ny mayngku kayal nuka-nya.
items.phonetic: n gaju bambajma-ɲ mayŋku kajal nuka-ɲa.
items.translation: I became sick from eating unripe mangoes.
They keep the word/message secret.
The child made the clothes dirty.
The child made the water dirty.
The girl overcooked the food.
Stoke the fire again!
Leave me alone!
He eloped with that woman.
Mother mistakenly sent the child to school (it was still too young).
crawl
get startled, get a fright
drown (itr)
faint
throw a tantrum
be exhausted, thirsty
cross-examine
sigh
beat time to corroboree
perspire

to burp
to break wind
imagine something
to sneeze
stagger, lurch
slip
spoil
There was an eclipse of the sun.
The wood turned into charcoal.
He went on again and moved eastwards.
He is moving into the sun.
I became an old woman.
Eventually Leonie will get married.
My house will move into the sun.
The two snakes wrap around each other.
The women are fighting; they stir each other up with a dance.
The women are fighting; they stir each other up with a dance.
He does not want to fight.
That man talks a lot, he is a chatterbox.
The cat is stretching itself.
All sorts of people turned up.
You lot, come here!
The children hide in the house.

items.transcript: Jana jalbu-ngku duda-l duda-l duda-l dudaaa-l.
items.phonetic: dʒana dʒalbu-ŋku duda-l duda-l duda-l dudaː-l.
items.translation: The women pound and pound and pound and pound.
He killed the wallaby with one shot.
The police came discreetly.

items.transcript: Kari bunda-y! Ngarri buyun. Yunu-nji nguyarr dara-y.
items.phonetic: kari bunda-j! ŋari bujun. junu-ɲi ŋujar dara-j.
items.translation: Don't sit down! [The bench] has a rotten leg. It will tip over with you.
I did not quite hit the tree with the stone (but the stone may have touched it in passing).
You look just right living in that caravan.
The rope is lying coiled up.
The old horse is walking slowly.
He quickly followed the stranger.
Put the eggs carefully on the plate!
Speak like this/make [it] like this!

items.transcript: N gayu warru-ku Palm Island bundanda-ny.
items.phonetic: n gaju waruku Palm Island bundandaɲ
items.translation: As a young man I stayed at Palm Island.

items.transcript: N gayu karrkay-nyja-ku minya kadar ngangkin nuka-l-nuka-ny.
items.phonetic: n gaju karkajɲdʒaku minja kadar ŋangkin nukalnukɲ
items.translation: As a child I used to eat wallaby and porcupine.
The man murdered him (intended to kill).
He looks like a pig.
Some places are just the same [as this place].
The old man also cried for his wife [just like the others].
I did not really sleep (I just dozed).

items.transcript: Jana kada-ny, kuyu mani-ny, waju-ny, nuka-ny-da.
items.phonetic: dʒana kadaɲ, kuju maniɲ, wajuɲ, nukɲda.
items.translation: They came, caught a fish, cooked [it], and then ate [it].
He caught a fish first, then speared a turtle.
The girl washed all the clothes thoroughly.
Sweep the whole house thoroughly!
I want to speak only to you.
Only the Islander felt sorry afterwards.
I am living by myself.
He is getting quite sick.
The blue tongue lizard bit the taipan again.
I want to come back.
I give you money.
I give you money and you, in tum, give me meat.

items.transcript: Monday yindu ngayu-ji school-mun-bu dunga-ny, Monday other ngayu-ji school-mun-LOC go-PAST mayi waju-nku.
items.phonetic: Monday jindu ŋayu-dʒi school-mun-bu duŋa-ɲ, Monday other ŋayu-dʒi school-mun-LOC go-PAST maji wadʒu-nku.
items.translation: Last Monday it was my tum to go to the school to cook food [i.e. school lunch].
It's your tum to sit down, I sweep the yard.
It's up to you.
I worked (lit: I was made to work).
A stinging tree burnt the child.
A stick poked me.
That was a man what [sic] hit the child.
Some man hit the child.
That wallaby is running.
Rain is coming.
The two old women sang out.
Father is resting.
Many trees are standing there.
The child is vomiting.
The widow[er] is sad.
I am exhausted.
The young man speared a sea turtle.
The pair of women set up camp.
The ghost met the child.
The man hit the dog by mistake.
That big eel bit the girl.
The eel [meat] made me sick.
The spider grabbed the mosquito.
A stonefish poked me.
A jellyfish burnt himlher.
The man speared the stingray with a three-pronged spear.

items.transcript: N gayu mayi yala-ku dingka-l mara-bu
items.phonetic: n gaju maji jala-ku diŋka-l mara-bu
items.translation: I squeeze the fruit like this with my hand.
The young man chased the dog with a snake.
The women are walking on foot.
The girl is kneeling.
My mother is cutting meat with a knife.
My mother cut herself with a knife.
A tree hit me.
I was hit with/by a tree.
A stinging tree burnt him.
He was burnt with/by a stinging tree.
I was poked by a stonefish.
He was burnt by a jellyfish.
A snake bit him.
He was bitten by a snake.
I am sweeping the ground for a camp.
He goes to Cooktown for his elder brother.

items.transcript: Bama-ngka nganya binal-bunga-l kuku-ku / mayi-ka minya-ka bubu-ku bama-nka
items.phonetic: bama-ŋka ŋaɲa binal-buŋa-l kuku-ku / maji-ka miɲa-ka bubu-ku bama-ŋka
items.translation: Aborigines teach me about [their] language, "bush-tucker", land [and] Aboriginal people.
I like bandicoot a lot.
I like [my pet] bandicoot a lot.
The man cried because of his mother.
They are eating because of the baby.
We two are fighting over food.
I was glad about the water.
The child is afraid of crabs.

items.transcript: N gayku babarr wawubaja-nga kari dunga-y bilngkumu-nku
items.phonetic: n gaju babar wawudʒaja-ŋa kari duŋaj bilŋkumu-nku
items.translation: My elder sister does not go to the river because of the crocodile.
I am running because of the vicious dog.
I asked Mabel about her new house.
A sea turtle is a lot bigger than a freshwater turtle.
Grandmother dug up a lot more scrub hen eggs than mother.

items.transcript: Nyulu julmbanu yala maja bubu-ku Australia-ka
items.phonetic: ɲulu dʒulmbanu jala madʒa bubu-ku Australia-ka
items.translation: The big grey kangaroo is like the boss of Australia.
We swam to the island.
The young fellows went out for pigs.
Charlie went to the horses.
I show the meat to the cat.
He gave the gun to his elder brother.

items.transcript: Ngayu yunu mayi yunga-l ngayku-wun-bu ngamu-ndu.
items.phonetic: ŋaju junu maji jungal ŋajkuwunbu ŋamundu.
items.translation: I will send your food with my mother.
The boss sent a message with the policeman.
The girls are bathing in the water.
Charlie is sitting on a horse.
The man killed a wallaby in the scrub.
A snake is lying under the log.

items.phonetic: kidʒa dʒambul-munj ŋaju duŋa j badʒa Cairns-munj
items.translation: After two months I will leave Cairns.
The woman chases the dog from the house.
A younger brother must not eat food from [his] elder sister.
The woman is weaving a bag from reed grass.
The man made a belt from the carpet snake.
I am sick from the bad meat.
He is hiding from the police.
The chickens are running from the carpet snake.
Mabel is singing out from the house.
They are throwing the fruit from the tree.
Green ant juice entered through the nose and through the eyes.
They swam through the river.
The man is going along the road.
That one is my younger sister.
That billycan is grandmother's.
That is good food. OR That food is good.
Granny is in the house.
The children are down there.
My mother is from Shiptons Flat.
That is fish from the sea.
His spear is blunt.
I have three children.
My child is bigger than her child.
The flame tree has flowers.
Do you have any matches?
He is stupid.
The old man has no hair.
He is ugly.
Aborigines are dark(-skinned).

items.transcript: N gayu karrkay -- yala Eileen-anga kangkal.
items.phonetic: n gaju karrkaj -- jala Eileen-aŋa kaŋkal.
items.translation: I was a child like Eileen's child (about the same age).
The jellyfish's tentacles are like cotton.
That man looks like a wallaby.
The girl is afraid.
The girl is afraid of snakes.
The dog wants a bone.
That food has become good.
She has become an old woman.
Granny is moving into the house.
The children are moving down.
His spear became blunt.
Soon the flame tree will get flowers.
He is getting stupid.
The girl became frightened.
The man has made his spear blunt.
The crocodile made that woman his wife.
The ghost frightened the girl.
The wind makes me shiver.
Charlie made the horse get up.
That old Aboriginal man made the police tum back.
I am looking for [my] dog.
I lost [my] dog.
The man hid the woman.
The man eloped with the woman.
Cat and dog are biting each other.
The men are fighting (lit. hitting each other).
The two dogs are licking each other.
They ignore each other.
He/she shook.
The girl shook.
The girl shook [something].
He/she was being shaken [by someone].
The child is washing itself.
The widow kept cutting herself.
He keeps scratching himself.
The young man hit himself by mistake.
The widow cut herself because of her husband.
The old woman poked her foot while digging for food.
I paint my lips.
He got tangled up in the fishing line.

items.transcript: Nyulu jalbu naybu-bu yaka-ji-ny minya yaka-l-yaka-nya.
items.phonetic: ɲulu dʒalbu najbu-bu jaka-dʒi-ɲ minja jaka-l-jaka-ɲa.
items.translation: The woman cut herself with a knife while cutting meat.
A shark bit the young man.
The young man was bitten (by a shark).
The woman happened to poke a snake.
The cattle happened to forage my mangoes.
I happened to see you.
The man happened to step on my foot.
Grandmother happened to smash the yam to tiny pieces.
The man accidentally stepped on my foot.
The woman accidentally poked a snake.
The young man was taken by a groper.
I was given a fright by the crocodile.
The young man was taken by a groper.
I was bitten (stung) by a scorpion.
That Aborigine was grabbed by the police.
Meat is roasting in the fire.
The store is closed today.
The girl looks nice. (lit. is good to look at [by anyone])
This food tastes nice. (lit. is good to eat by anyone)
[If] [you or someone] happen to see any mangoes, take [bring] them!
Zamia nuts were gathered [by someone].
The girl was ridiculed (lit. laughed about) by the young man.
The man had a good feed of meat (he wasted nothing).
That little one is hitting all the dogs (around here).
The Aborigine went and threw curses everywhere.
The woman is looking around for yam.
The woman is having a sticky-beak in all the other houses.
The woman is searching for yam.
The dog is foraging through the food.
The woman is having a look through all the other houses.
Mother shared out all the food.

items.phonetic: ɲulu dʒalbu ŋajku-wun-bu bajan-ba ŋun dʒa-dʒi-ɲ.
items.translation: The woman took over my house lock stock and barrel.
The man called me.
The man asked me for food.
The child pestered mother for a lolly.
The police asked the young man about the grog.
I went for a walk andlwhile he stayed at home.

items.transcript: Babarr-angka mayi waju-l, jinkurr-ungku eZ-ERG:pt(A) food.ABS(O) cook-NONPAST yZ-ERG:pt(A) ngawa nyaji-l-nyaji-l
items.phonetic: babar-angka maju-l, dʒinkur-uŋku eZ-ERG:pt(A) food.ABS(O) cook-NONPAST yZ-ERG:pt(A) ŋawa ɲadʒi-l-ɲadʒi-l
items.translation: Elder sister is cooking food andlwhile younger sister is watching the baby.

items.transcript: N gayu yarraman karrba-l, yundu daka-l
items.phonetic: n gaju jarraman karba-l, jundu daka-l
items.translation: I hold the horse andlwhile you climb up.

items.transcript: Nyulu yindu nyunba-ny-baja, kangkal-kangkal nyungu wubul-ku mani-ny, wundi-ny badabada bayan-ba, camp-LOC milbi-ny-da
items.phonetic: ɲulu jindu ɲunba-ny-baja, kaŋkal-kaŋkal ɲungu wubul-ku mani-ny, wundi-ny badabada bajan-ba, milbi-ny-da
items.translation: The other one turned back again, fetched her many children, brought them down to the camp and showed them.
[If] you had come, you would have seen me.

items.transcript: Bula warru-ngku nambarr kulba-ny, kaja-ny, dunga-ny-baja
items.phonetic: bula warru-ŋku nambar kulba-ny, kaja-ny, dunga-ɲ-baja
items.translation: The two young men pulled out the bamboo, wrapped it up and went on again.

items.transcript: Nyulu dingkar bunda-ny, minya-nga nuka-ji-ny, wunana-ny-da
items.phonetic: ɲulu diŋkar bunda-ɲ, minja-ŋa nuka-dʒi-ɲ, wunana-ɲ-da
items.translation: The man sat down, had a good feed of meat and then had a rest.
The man came in and the woman hit him.
The man entered and the woman happened to hit [him].

items.transcript: Ngayu buwun-ji dunga-ny, kari muyar junkuji.
items.phonetic: ŋaju buwun-dʒi dunga-ɲ, kari muyar dʒunku-dʒi.
items.translation: I went out with a boat, but there was a strong wind.

items.transcript: lalbu yinya wawu baduri-ji dunga-nka, kari nyulu bambay.
items.phonetic: lalbu jinya wawu baduri-dʒi dunga-nka, kari ɲulu bambaj.
items.translation: That woman would like to go fishing, but she is sick.

items.transcript: N gayu nyaji-nka yinya bama, kari kalakalbay-bajaku.
items.phonetic: n gayu ɲadʒi-nka jinya bama, kari kalakalbaj-bajaku.
items.translation: I am trying to see that person, but [he is] too far away.

items.transcript: Nyulu warru-ngku kuyu mani-ny, kari burrki-n-burrki-n.
items.phonetic: ɲulu warru-ŋku kuyu mani-ɲ, kari burrki-n-burrki-n.
items.translation: The young man got the fish [on the line], but [it] kept on fidgeting/struggling.
That port (suitcase) is small, but [it] is heavy.

items.transcript: Kaki yundu yinya kaya juku-bu kuni-l yununybayka-l.
items.phonetic: kaki jundu jinya kaj dʒuku-bu kuni-l yununybayka-l.
items.translation: If you hit that dog with a stick, [it] will bite you.

items.transcript: Kaki ngayu ngiki-ji dumbarri-l, ngayu yangka nuka-l.
items.phonetic: kaki ŋaju ŋiki-dʒi dumbarri-l, ŋaju yangka nuka-l.
items.translation: If I have a cough/cold, I break up green ants and eat [them].

items.transcript: Nyulu warngku-wuna-y, kaki nyulu bangkarr bajaburray.
items.phonetic: ɲulu warŋku-wuna-j, kaki ɲulu baŋkar bajaburaj.
items.translation: He has a sleep, if he feels tired.
(If/when) he was exhausted, he had a sleep.

items.transcript: Ngayu bana wundi-l, kunka bana kari baral-darr.
items.phonetic: ŋaju bana wundi-l, kunka bana kari baral-darr.
items.translation: I take some water in case there is no water along the road.

items.transcript: Ngayu bana wundi-l. Yinya-ngkarr bana yambakari.
items.phonetic: ŋaju bana wundi-l. jinya-ŋkarr bana yambakari.
items.translation: I take some water. There is no water at all along the road.

items.transcript: Nyulu ngayku kambi julurri-l, ngayu-ji nyungu-nku mayi waju-l.
items.phonetic: ɲulu ŋayku kambi dʒuluri-l, ŋaju-dʒi ɲungu-nku mayi waju-l.
items.translation: She washes my clothes and I in turn cook food for her.

items.transcript: Jalbu-ngku nganya kuni-ny, ngayu-ji nyunguny kuni-ny.
items.phonetic: dʒalbu-ŋku ŋanja kuni-ɲ, ŋaju-dʒi ɲuŋuɲ kuni-ɲ.
items.translation: The woman hit me and I in turn hit her [back].
The woman looked after the child.
I'd better cook some food. [I am] hungry.

items.transcript: Ngayku balji kadaba-ny. Ngayu balji jirakal balka-nka.
items.phonetic: ŋayku baldʒi kadaba-ɲ. ŋayu baldʒi dʒirakal balka-nka
items.translation: My bag is broken. I have to make a new bag.
You two get some grass for the soup!

items.phonetic: jubal wudu dʒu mana, milkul nuka-nka
items.translation: You two get some grass for eating the soup!
The child moves and as a result gets born.
The women sat down to have a chat.
The young man went to the river to spear fish.
The woman stood up so that [her] husband could see her.

items.phonetic: ɲulu dʒawun-kara-nda kundiʒadʒi-ɲ, maji da dʒi-nka
items.translation: He asked [his] friends to give [him] some food.
Mother is cooking fish in order to eat [it].
Grandmother drinks green ant [something] in order to get better.
I beat (on) the tree so that the people can hear [me].

items.phonetic: ŋayu dʒalbu kunʒa-ɲ, bulkidʒi da dʒi-nka
items.translation: I summoned/ordered the woman to give [me] some clams.
Elder sister is making a bag for mother to carry.
The police summoned the young man to come.
Grandmother told the girl to look after the baby.
I spread a sheet to sit on.
Elder brother told [his] younger sister to run.
The woman told [her] niece to light a fire.
He goes to the new house to have a peep [at it].
I go to the boss to ask [him].
Granny takes the child so that [he/she/it] be happy.

items.transcript: Kami-ngka karrkay wundi-l, baya FF/MM-ERG:pt(A) child.ABS(O) take-NONPAST firewood.ABS(O) gather-PURP muja-nka.
items.translation: Granny takes the child to gather firewood.

items.transcript: Kami-ngka maral wundi-ny, nyulu kambi nyungu mani-nka.
items.phonetic: kami-ŋka maral wundi-ɲ, ɲulu kambi ɲungu mani-nka
items.translation: Granny took the girl so that she (the girl) will get her clothes.
I light a fire so that you get warm.

items.transcript: Dunyu-ngku kamukamu kari nuka-l, manyarr ... wawurrwawurr-ma-nka.
items.phonetic: dunyu-ŋku kamukamu kari nuka-l, manyar wawurrwawurr-ma-nka
items.translation: The husband does not drink alcohol so that [his] wife is happy.
He wants some meat.
He wants to eat.
He wants to eat meat.
I want them to get some turtle.
I am afraid of the dark.
I am afraid to go out in the dark.
This is drinking water/water for drinking.
That is rubbish for burning.
He does not bathe in the river lest [he] drown.

items.transcript: Kari kalka-ji nguju-wuri-y, yundu ngawa kuni-nyji.
items.phonetic: kari kalka-dʒi ŋudʒu-wuri-j, jundu ŋawa kuni-ɲdʒi.
items.translation: Don't play/fool around with the spear lest you hit the baby!

items.transcript: BamaAborigine.ABS(S) kari jikan-baNEG grass-LOC kalbay-mba dunga-n-dunga-y,long-LOC go-n-REDUP-NONPAST; jarba-busnake-ERG(A) bayka-nyji.bite-PRECAUT
items.phonetic: bamaaborigine.ABS(S) kari dʒikan-baNEG grass-LOC kalbaj-mba duŋa-n-duŋaj, long-LOC go-n-REDUP-NONPAST; dʒarba-busnake-ERG(A) bajka-ɲji.bite-PRECAUT
items.translation: Aborigines don't walk through long grass lest a snake bite [them].
Young men don't drink alcohol lest [they] fight.
Don't cook the food lest you spoil [it] !
Don't touch the vicious dog lest [it] bite [you].

items.transcript: Babarr-angka karrkay-karrkay kanga-ny, nyunguny kuni-nyji. Karrkay kuli-baka.
items.phonetic: babar-ŋka karkaj-karkaj kanga-ɲ, ɲuŋuɲ kuni-ɲadʒi. karkaj kuli-baka.
items.translation: Elder sister chases the children away, lest they hit her. The children are a wild lot.
I carry the baby lest [it] cry.

items.transcript: Bula jalbu-ngku dubu waJu-ny, kangkal ngaki-nyji-baja.
items.phonetic: bula dʒalbu-ŋku dubu wadʒu-ɲ, kangkal ŋaki-ɲadʒi-badʒa.
items.translation: The two women burnt the ghost lest [he] steal [their] children again.
Don't pick up the egg lest you drop [it] !

items.transcript: Nyulu wawu kari kaya-nda dunga-nka, (kaya-ngka) / (nyulu) bayka-nyji.
items.phonetic: ɲulu wawu kari kaja-nda dunga-nka, (kaja-ŋka) / (ɲulu) bajka-ɲadʒi.
items.translation: He doesn't want to go to the dog, lest (the dog)/(it) bite [him].
Keep a fire burning lest it get cold!
That fish might get rotten.

items.transcript: Ngayu jinbal-da-ku jarba kuni-ny, nganya bayka-nyjiku.
items.phonetic: ŋaju dʒinbal-da-ku dʒarba kuni-ɲ, ŋaɲa bajka-ɲadʒiku.
items.translation: I quickly killed the snake before [it] might bite me.
I had a rest before going for a walk.

items.transcript: lalbu mara julurri-ji-y, mayi damba dingka-nyjiku.
items.phonetic: lalbu mara dʒuluri-dʒi-j, maji damba diŋka-ɲdʒiku.
items.translation: The woman washes [her] hands before kneading damper.
The girl stocks up clothes before getting married.
She sweeps the ground before setting up camp.
The women roast the zamia nuts before pounding them.

items.transcript: lalbujalbungku marra dindal, maral-maral-angka marra duda-l-da.
items.phonetic: lalbu-dʒalbu-ŋku marra dinda-l, maral-maral-aŋka marra duda-l-da.
items.translation: The women roast the zamia nuts, then the girls pound the nuts.

items.transcript: Ngayu kaya karrba-ny, nyulu ngayku minya bangkarr nuka-nyjiku.
items.phonetic: ŋaju kaja karba-ɲ, ɲulu ŋajku minja baŋkar nuka-ɲdʒiku.
items.translation: I grabbed the dog before it ate my steak.
They saw the wallaby before it ran away.
A bird cries before rain falls, [that is] the rainbird.
I went before the wind came.

items.transcript: Nganjin bibikarrbi wunana-ny, ngayku nganjan wundi-nyjiku waybala-ngka Palm Island.
items.phonetic: ŋanjin bibikarrbi wunana-ɲ, ŋajku nganjan wundi-ɲdʒiku wajbala-ŋka Palm Island.
items.translation: We were living at Helenvale before white people took my father to Palm Island.
I heard you chewing food noisily.
The Aborigine watched the Chinese digging for gold.
The groper grabbed in passing the chap spearing turtles.
The policeman shot him while he was running.
I am watching the wallaby feeding on grass.
The Aborigine watched while/how the Chinese was digging for gold.
I saw how he cut up the bullock [carcass].
The girl watched while/how the Aborigines danced a corroboree.
The child saw the snake being killed.

items.transcript: N gayu wulman-anda dunga-y, yinyay bundanda-nya.
items.phonetic: n gaju wulman-anda dunga-j, jinyaj bundanda-ɲa
items.translation: I go to the old man (who is?) sitting there.
I go to the sitting old man.
They run to the woman (who is?) cooking food.
They run to the food-cooking woman.
The woman used to give (teach) me language while sitting down.

items.transcript: Jana3pl.NOM(A) warru-ngkuyg.man-ERG:pt(A) kinka-n-kinka-nya kamukamuplay-n-REDUP-SUB alcohol.ABS(O) nuka-l-nuka-l.drink-l-REDUP-NONPAST
items.phonetic: dʒana3pl.NOM(A) warru-ŋkuyg.man-ERG:pt(A) kinka-n-kinka-ɲa kamukamuplay-n-redup-sub alcohol.ABS(O) nuka-l-nuka-l.drink-l-redup-nonpast
items.translation: The young men drink alcohol while playing (cards).
The women make the zamia nut (into a) fine powder, pounding it.

items.transcript: Dingkar-angka kalka dudu kulji-bu kida-I-kida-nya man-ERG:pt(A) spear.ABS(O) blunt-ABS stone-INST scrape-l-REDUP-SUB nyurrba-l.
items.phonetic: diŋkar-angka kalka dudu kuldʒi-bu kida-i-kida-ɲa man-ERG:pt(A) spear.ABS(O) blunt-ABS stone-INST scrape-l-redup-sub ɲurrba-l
items.translation: The man sharpens the blunt spear, scraping it with a stone.
The girl watched the Aborigines while she was dancing.

items.transcript: N gamu-ngku ngawa kuji-I-kuji-l, mayi nuka-I-nuka-nya-mun-du.
items.phonetic: n gamu-ŋku ŋgawa kudʒi-i-kudʒi-l, mayi nuka-i-nuka-ɲa-mun-du
items.translation: Mother looks after the baby while she is eating.
The policeman shot him while he (the policeman) was running.
That horse sleeps standing up.
Climbing on the tree, he fell.
Holding on to the snake, he called out.
The two chaps went along planting bamboo (all the way).
The child runs crying.
The sick man sleeps tossing and turning.

items.transcript: Bula maral baral-ba kankada-y, mayngku nuka-l-nuka-nya.
items.phonetic: bula maral baral-ba kankada-j, majŋku nuka-l-nuka-ɲa
items.translation: The two girls are coming on the road eating mangoes.
The woman was chatting, ignoring her husband.
I have a sore back while/from gathering firewood.

items.transcript: Ngayu muku kaka, baya muja-nya yilayku.
items.phonetic: ŋaju muku kaka, baja mudʒa-ɲa jilajku.
items.translation: I have a sore back from gathering firewood yesterday.
He is tired from bathing.
He choked from gobbling down food.
The policeman did not see me because [he] was asleep.
Elder sister is searching for the child because [she] lost [it].
The two took the child (with them) because (it) felt lonely.

items.transcript: N ganjan-angka kangkal murrukanga-l, kaya jabi-nya.
items.phonetic: n ɡadʒan-angka kaŋkal murukanga-l, kaja dʒabi-ɲa
items.translation: Father is scolding [his] child because [it] kicked the dog.
After bathing, they have a rest.
We saw the woman after [she] had come in.
The man killed the Brown Snake after [it] had bitten [him].
I had a rest after washing clothes.
She went for a walk after having fed the chickens.
The young man grabbed the dog after it had barked (lit. after the barking).
She drank some water after the walk.

items.transcript:
Ngayu1sg.NOM(A) bayanhouse.ABS(O) kida-l,sweep-NONPAST dayirr-bunga-l,clean-CAUS-NONPAST

items.translation: I sweep the house and clean it in case my friend comes [to visit].

kunka nyulu bambay-ma-nya-mun-ku. in.case 3sg.NOM(S) sick-INCHO-SUB-mun-DAT

items.translation: Grandfather takes medicine for the road in case he gets sick.

items.translation: The girl took a billycan in case she came across some quandong fruit.

items.phonetic:

items.translation: Uncle goes with (takes) a stick in case the dog bites (attacks) him.

items.phonetic: N gayu markin wundi-l, ŋuba 1sg.NOM(A) gun.ABS(O) take-NONPAST perhaps 1sg-LOC bikibiki ɲadʒl-dʒl-j. pig(s).ABS(S) see-I1R-NONPAST (ngayku-ndu)

items.translation: 1 take a gun, perhaps (1) happen to see some pigs.
A thunderstorm struck the cow [which was/while it was] standing on the mountain.

items.transcript: Nyulu dingkar nyaji-l-nyaji-ny, bana wulji-l-wulji-nya buwun-muny.
items.phonetic: ɲulu diŋkar ɲadʒi-l-ɲadʒi-ɲa, bana wuldʒi-l-wuldʒi-ɲa buwun-munɲ.
items.translation: He watched the man [who was] bailing water from the boat.

items.transcript: Nyulu nyaji-l-nyaji-ny, dingkar-angka bana wulji-l-wulji-inya buwun-muny.
items.phonetic: ɲulu ɲadʒi-l-ɲadʒi-ɲa, diŋkar-aŋka bana wuldʒi-l-wuldʒi-inya buwun-munɲ.
items.translation: He watched [while] the man was bailing water from the boat.
The girl watches the bird [while] standing up.

items.transcript: Nyulu jalbu-ngku dunyu bawa-ny. Nyulu yinyay bundanda-y kangkal-ji.
items.phonetic: ɲulu dʒalbu-ŋku dunju bawa-ɲ. ɲulu yinyay bundanda-j kaŋkal-dʒi.
items.translation: The woman left her husband. She [who] is sitting there with her child.

items.transcript: Nyulu yinya mala-minya. Nyulu bama wawubaja-nga dunga-y.
items.phonetic: ɲulu jinja mala-miɲa. ɲulu bama wawubadʒa-ŋa dunga-j.
items.translation: That one is a good hunter. The Aborigine [who] is walking to the river.

items.transcript: Ngayu ngawuya wawu daji-nka ngayku-wun-du jawun-undu. Nyulu yilayku kada-ny.
items.phonetic: ŋaju ŋawuya wawu dʒaji-nka ŋayku-wun-du dʒawun-undu. ɲulu dʒilayku kada-ɲ.
items.translation: I want to give turtle [meat] to my friend. He [who] came yesterday.
I go to the river to catch a fish...
... lest I get hungry.
... in case I get hungry.
... before I clean the house.
... after I clean the house.

items.phonetic: (5 1 2) ŋan dʒan amu kaja dʒinbal-ku wanarri-j.
items.translation: Father's dog is running fast.
The scales of the fish are big and plentiful.
The fish of in (lit. of) the river are good.
The man's elder brother killed a pig.
I am learning about Aborigines' food.
We put everything into Chris's Toyota.
I don't like your father's dog.
His hair is wet.
He hooked the fish (on) the tail.

items.phonetic: ɲulu kuldʒi daraʒ mani-ɲ maral-anda jina-ŋa.
items.translation: He dropped the stone on the girl's foot.
I have two children.
I have many granddaughters.
The leaves on this tree/from this tree are very big.
Fruit onlfrom that tree is good to eat.
The shell on/of/*from the zamia nut is hard.
That is my former husband.

items.phonetic: jiɲa bajan dʒalbu ndul ndumuɲ mali
items.translation: That house formerly belonged to a woman.

items.transcript: Bula jalbu-bulal-angka mayi kubarr daji-ny dingkar-anda
items.phonetic: bula dʒalbu-bulal-aŋka maji kubar daji-ɲ diŋkar-anda
items.translation: The two women gave the eel to the man.
I gave mother [her] food.
That dog is vicious.
The child needs to have a pee.
The sea is rough.
The egg has a soft shell.
That man has a beard.
They are people of light forest country.
The woman has many clothes.
That man has three spears.
hot season
cold season
His grandfather died in the hot season.
The young man killed the vicious snake.
The man with the beard speared many mullet.

items.transcript: Ngayu wawu jirray juku-ku birra-jirr-ka jabajaba-jirr-ka.
items.phonetic: ŋayu wawu dʒirray dʒuku-ku birra-dʒirr-ka dʒabajaba-dʒirr-ka.
items.translation: I like very much the tree with the many big leaves.
Grandmother gave green ant [juice] to the child with the cough.
He came from that house with the tree.
I came with [my] aunt.
The young men are going out for pigs with a dog/dogs.
She is sitting in the house with the baby.
He went down the river with a dinghy.
The old man is going out with a spear and an axe.
[Our] friend is sitting with papers/books and a tape-recorder.
That dog is playing with a bone.
The young man is dancing with his younger sister.
They are stupid.
J don't have a cold, [I am] well again.
The old woman has no teeth.
The one without hair stole my shoes.
The homeless one is sad.
We have no tea.
J gave clothes to the childless woman.
He went without a rifle.
The baby sleeps without a blanket.

items.transcript: Ngayu kari jilba-dunga-y jalbu-nji, ngayu-rrku dunga-y.
items.phonetic: ŋayu kari dʒilba-dunga-j dʒalbu-ndʒi, ŋayu-rku dunga-j.
items.translation: J don't go walkabout with the women, J go by myself.
Wash yourselves !
Don't blame [your] mother !
Drop that!
(You two) keep sitting there, I will come back.
Come on, let's go now!
Let him/her go!
Let it burn!
Let him eat his food!
Eat straight away (before you do anything else)!
Have you seen my child?
Did he come back?
Who came with the boss?
Who took my shoes?
With whom did you go to Cooktown?
What did you put in the bag?
What (sort of) food do you want/like?
Where is he from?

items.phonetic: wadʒa wadʒa jundu kada-j-ba dʒa, wuŋaridʒi?
items.translation: When will you come back, (in the) hot season?
How many Aborigines live there?
They don't know the language nowadays.
The woman knows how to weave dillybags.
The man is good at/with cattle.
I'm afraid of crocodiles.
The children love to play.
He wants to make a spear.
The child wantsllikes to hide.
I learn language.

items.transcript: (592) Kambakamba-ngka nganya binal-bunga-ny mayi-ka jarruka baka-nka
items.phonetic: kambakamba-ŋka ŋaɲa binal buŋa ɲ maji-ka ; dʒaruka baka-nka
items.translation: The old women taught me about food (and) how to dig scrub hen (eggs).
I did not break the billycan.
I did not break the billycan [but something else].
I did not break the billycan [but something else did].
Not a ghost is coming, [but] a man.
The ghost is not coming, [but] going.
I am not hungry.
I am not hungry.
The young man could not spear the turtle.
I don't like fighting.
I don't like to smoke.
I don't like half-ripe mangoes.
I don't want/don't like to smoke.
He is (just) like his father.
Eskimos are expert hunters like Aborigines.

items.transcript: Ngayu wawu jirray mayi-ka yala mayngku.
items.phonetic: ŋaju wawu dʒirraj maji-ka jala majŋku.
items.translation: I like very much fruit [that is] like a mango.

items.transcript: N gayu mayi wundi-ny yala nyulu ngadiku.
items.phonetic: n gaju maji-wundi-ɲ jala ɲulu ŋadiku.
items.translation: I brought food like he brought it long ago.

items.transcript: Jana wanjabu? N guba jana ngaki-ji-y.
items.phonetic: dʒana wandʒabu? n guba dʒana ŋaki-dʒi-j.
items.translation: Where are they? Maybe they are hiding.

items.transcript: Nguba ngayu nyiku kada-y-baja, nguba wunkuny.
items.phonetic: ŋuba ŋaju ɲiku kada-j-bada, ŋuba wunkuɲ.
items.translation: Maybe I come back today (or) maybe tomorrow.

items.transcript: guba ngayu kuyu nyama-l, nguba dinda-l.
items.phonetic: guba ŋaju kuju ɲama-l, ŋuba dinda-l.
items.translation: Maybe I 'll stew the fish, maybe [I'll] roast it.
Pastor, he ...
John Robert's child ...
An old woman ...
My elder brother and I caught a lot of fish.
You and Roderick have a swim!
A pair of two young fellows ...
You and I and the children will go walkabout tomorrow.

items.transcript: Ngayu babi I sg.NOM(S) FM.ABS(S) wulbuman yindu ngamu old.woman.ABS(S) other.ABS(S) mother.ABS(S) nganjin dunga-ri-ny mayi baka-nka.
items.phonetic: ŋaju babi I sg.NOM(S) FM.ABS(S) wulbuman jindu ŋamu old.woman.ABS(S) other.ABS(S) mother.ABS(S) ŋadʒin duŋa-ri-ɲ maji baka-nka.
items.translation: I, grandmother, another old woman and mother, we went out to dig for food (yams).
We all including Mabel had a long chat.
You children go and get water!

items.transcript: Jalbu-jalbu karrkay-karrkay jana wawubaja-nga dunga-ny mukirr mani-nka.
items.phonetic: dʒalbu-dʒalbu karkaj-karkaj dʒana wawubaja-ŋa duŋa-ɲ mukirr mani-nka.
items.translation: Women and children, they went to the river to get mussels.
Doris and her people came back.
The child was sleeping.
His camp was on top of the mountain.
There was this old man.
That child, he had a dream.
... that child (went) down. That one dived.
A whole lot of people turned up ...
Grandmother missed [the fish] with the digging stick.
While I in tum hacked vainly in the water with a knife.

items.transcript: Nganjin wawubaja-nga kada-ny tent ngara-ny mayi nuka-ny wuna-ny-da.
items.phonetic: ŋanjin wawubadʒa-ŋa kada-ɲ tent ŋara-ɲ mayi nuka-ɲ wuna-ɲ-da.
items.translation: We came to the river, set up tent, ate some food and then rested.
[It] grabbed [him], then took [him with it] and dived.
I first cook the fish and then I take it [with me].
Queenie was the first to find (lit. get) an egg.
After the sleep they went on.
Since that time I have grown up.
They came to the Jeannie River.

items.transcript: Bulakada-ny, bula wawubaja-nga dunga-ny.3du.NOM(S) come-PAST 3du.NOM(S) river-LOC go-PAST
items.phonetic: bulakadɲ bula wawubadʒaŋa dungɲ come-PAST 3du river-LOC go-PAST
items.translation: They came and they went to the river.

items.transcript: Bula wawubaja-nga dunga-ny, bula mayi3du.NOM(S) river-LOC go-PAST 3du.NOM(A) fruit.ABS(O) kabal warrmba-bunga-ny.Leichardt.tree.ABS(O) uncovered-CAUS-PAST

items.translation: They went to the river and they found some Leichardt tree fruit.
Leichardt fruit [they] found.

items.transcript: Nyulu jina yijarri-ny murraJa-nga Nyunguniny murraja-bu baka-ny
items.phonetic: ɲulu dʒina jidʒarriɲ murradʒaŋa ɲunguniny murradʒabu bakaɲ
items.translation: He put [his] foot on a stonefish. The stonefish poked him.

items.transcript: Chris kangkal-bulal dingkar-bulal ngayku kangkal-kangkal ngayu janangan murrukanga-ny
items.phonetic: kris kaŋkal-bulal diŋkar-bulal ŋajku kaŋkal-kaŋkal ŋaju dʒanangan murrukangaɲ
items.translation: I scolded them, Chris and my two sons:
Some were killed ...
He got a really big rock.
He sat and watched.

items.transcript: Waybala janyiman, jana Palmer River kada-ny mani-nka.
items.phonetic: wajbala dʒaɲiman, dʒana Palmer River kada-ɲ mani-nka
items.translation: White men and Chinese, they came to the Palmer River to get gold.
White men, they killed many Aborigines.
Many Aborigines, the white men killed them.

items.transcript: Bakarrmuku-muny kada-ny, kada-ny kada-ny kada-ny, Wakooka.Stn-ABL; bula yuwulbuwun kada-ny.
items.phonetic: bakarmuku-muɲ kadaɲ, kadaɲ kadaɲ kadaɲ, wakooka.stn; bula juwulbuwun kadaɲ.
items.translation: They came from Wakooka Station, came on and on and on, and they came to the Jeannie River.

items.transcript: Dunga-ny-da wulbuman wangkar dunga-ny kaya-nda mani-nka
items.phonetic: duŋaɲda wulbuman waŋkar duŋaɲ kajanda mani-nka
items.translation: Off went the old woman (leaving the two young fellows), went up to the dog to get [it].
They came and they went to the river.
We could not follow, the fish was swimming in the water.
But mother said: "You two spear it with a digging stick!"
We two came from the West.

items.transcript: UN gay, kari wangkar-muny ngayu kankada-ny.
items.phonetic: un gaj, kari waŋkar-muny ŋayu kankada-ɲ.
items.translation: I see, but I came from up there.

items.transcript: Walkarr kul-ji kari, dirra minya kabu nuka-ny.
items.phonetic: walkar kul-dʒi kari, dirra miɲa kabu nuka-ɲa.
items.translation: The black goanna is not vicious, but [its] teeth are full of germs from eating rotten meat.

items.transcript: J ana mala-minya bubu walu-yindu yala bama, yamba jana-nga
items.phonetic: dʒ ana mala-miɲa bubu walu-jindu jala bama, jamba dʒana-ŋa
items.translation: They (the Eskimos) are good hunters and fishermen like Aborigines, but their country is different.

items.transcript: Balu yundu minya dinda-nka, kari yundu
items.phonetic: balu jundu miɲa dinda-nka, kari jundu
items.translation: I thought you intended to roast the meat, but you are boiling it in water.
I thought he was coming back (but apparently he did not).

items.transcript:
Warru-bulal jambul, bula jilba-dunga-ny
dunga-ny dunga-ny, gO-PAST gO-PAST
items.phonetic:
waru-bulal dʒambul, bula dʒilba-duŋa-ɲ
duŋa-ɲ duŋa-ɲ, go-PAST go-PAST
items.translation: Two young men, they went walkabout, went on and on,
they came from the West, from somewhere (around) Wakooka Station.
they came to the Jeannie River.

items.transcript: Bula wawubaja-nga dunga-ny, bula 3du.NOM(S) river-LOC gO-PAST 3du.NOM(A) mayi kabal warrmba-bunga-ny.
items.phonetic: bula wawubaja-ŋa dunga-ɲ, bula 3du.NOM(S) river-LOC go-PAST 3du.NOM(A) mayi kabal warrmba-bunga-ɲ.
items.translation: They went to the river and they found some Leichardt fruit.
items.source: Bula wawubaja-nga dunga-ny, bula 3du.NOM(S) river-LOC gO-PAST 3du.NOM(A) mayi kabal warrmba-bunga-ny

items.transcript: Yundu dunga-y, yundu Palmer River kada-y
items.phonetic: jundu duŋaj, jundu palmer river kadaj
items.translation: You go, and you come to the Palmer River.

items.transcript: Yundu Palmer River kada-y, yundu yarra-nyaji-l wuburr jarrajarra wangkarsee-NONPAST
items.phonetic: jundu palmer river kadaj, jundu jarra-ɲadʒi-l wubar dʒarrajarra waŋkarsee-NONPAST
items.translation: You come to the Palmer River and you see over there somewhere a higher mountain top, [that is] Mount Windsor.
His camp [was] up there on the mountain top.
He lived in a cave.
He used to get up early and sit around.
[He] looked around to see smoke.
The policemen were going along,
(they were) lighting grassfires.
[Thus] he got to know: “Ah, that's the police!”
He came.
The child was sleeping.
Mother and father were sleeping.

items.transcript: Ah wuna-ny wuna-ny, Ah lie-PAST lie-PAST
items.phonetic: ah wuna-ɲ wuna-ɲ, ah lie-PAST lie-PAST
items.translation: Ah, [they] slept and slept,

items.transcript: yinya karrkay, nyulu bijarri-ny, bilngkumu bijarri-ny.
items.phonetic: jinya karrkaj, ɲulu bijarri-ɲ, bilngkumu bijarri-ɲ.
items.translation: that child, he dreamt, dreamt 'of' a crocodile.
In [the middle of] the night [he] did not sleep,
[he] cried out to father and mother:
Mother, daddy, wake up!
This crocodile is coming.
He had a dream.
[He] cried out, and cried and cried.
A whole lot of people turned up,

items.transcript: torch mani-ny, balba-ny balba-ny balba-ny bed-ba
items.phonetic: torch mani-ɲ, balba-ɲ balba-ɲ balba-ɲ bed-ba
items.translation: [they] got a torch and kept flashing a light on the bed,
and peeped under [the bed],
nothing [there was] nothing.
'Ah quick, look, look!'
His smell is coming, a strong smell.
It is close now, [it] is coming close.
[It] is coming close.
[The child] smelled the smell, the strong smell [of] crocodile.
[The people] flashed a light again.
[They] went along the side [of the house], came back, and looked in the house.
Ah, there is really nothing at all, perhaps he had a dream.
[He had] a very strong dream.

items.transcript: Wuna-ny, muduwaju-ny, yalibala jana mayi lie-PAST; waju-ny, nuka-ny mayi, dunga-ny-da.
items.phonetic: wuna-ɲ, muduwaju-ɲ, yalibala jana mayi lie-PAST; waju-ɲ, nuka-ɲ mayi, dunga-ɲ-da.
items.translation: [They] lay down, dawn came, early [in the morning] they cooked food, ate breakfast and then went out.
[They] went out and dived for mussels in the river.
[They] gathered mussels and that child [went] down.
That [child] dived.
[He] got mussels and threw them out.
[He] threw some onto the land (shore).
[He] dived again going into deep water.
They called [him]:
Don't go into deep water, that [is] deep water!
Come close into shallow water!
No, [I am] all right.
There were so many mussels; many mussels.
[He] went in again, gathered more and threw them out.
Ah, a crocodile came, that [very same] from the dream.
[It] came straight towards the child.
[It] grabbed [him].
[It] grabbed [him], then took [him with it] and dived.

items.transcript: lana karrkay-anga nganjan ngamu kanbal bama yirrka-ri-ny.
items.phonetic: lana karrkay-anga ŋanjan ngamu kanbal bama jirrka-ri-ny
items.translation: They, the child's father and mother and some people, cried out.
Ah, [they] then searched [everywhere].
The crocodile went under and came out again.
[It] showed [the child] like that (gesture) to the mother.
[The mother?] was very sad/upset.
[The crocodile] went down [again].
Well, they kept searching.
[It] went under, over there it went under.
[The crocodile] came up again and showed [the child].
That's it there, quick, quick!
That was it.
It was all finished, [the crocodile] had taken [the child].
[It was] just like the dream.

items.transcript: N ganjin mayi mani-ny, nganjin dunga-ny-da.
items.phonetic: n gandʒin maji maniɲ, ŋandʒin dungaɲda.
items.translation: We got some food and then we went.

items.transcript: Kaba-nga-ku nganjin dunga-ny, dunga-ny, dunga-ny, dunga-ny.
items.phonetic: kaba-ŋa-ku ŋandʒin dungaɲ, dungaɲ, dungaɲ, dungaɲ.
items.translation: We went in the rain, went on and on and on.

items.transcript: Kaba-nga-ku warri-ny, baral-ba kada-ny maja-nga, bubu julbarr.
items.phonetic: kaba-ŋa-ku wariɲ, baral-ba kadaɲ madʒa-ŋa, bubu dʒulabar.
items.translation: [We] drove (lit. ran) in the rain and came to the road in the scrub; the ground was slippery.
My children were in the back of the Toyota.

items.transcript: N galiny ngayku dunyu jakalba nganjin Chris.
items.phonetic: n galinj ŋajku dunju dʒakalba ŋandʒin Chris.
items.translation: My husband and I were in the front together with Chris.

items.transcript: lana kaykay-angka nyaji-ny warru-warru-ngku maral-maral-angka bubu julbarr-bi.
items.phonetic: lana kajkaj-aŋka ɲadʒiɲ warru-warru-ŋku maral-maral-aŋka bubu dʒulabar-bi.
items.translation: The children, the boys and girls, saw the really slippery ground.
There was heavy rain.
Shall we turn back?
The pastor came from there, [he] had turned back.

items.transcript: Nyungu pastor-mu motorcar kari daka-ny, yinya balay karrkay.
items.phonetic: ɲungu pastor-mu motorcar kari dakaɲ, dʒiɲa balaj karkaj.
items.translation: The pastor's car could not go up, it [that] was low and small.
The pastor had turned back again.
